Below is an exam question and a sample answer.

assessment objective. Add some more annotations to show what’s good and what could be improved.

three reasons
The answer continues on the next page...
1)b)How does Shakespeare present the theme of appearance and reality in ?
Macbeth
In ‘Macbeth’, Shakespeare presents appearance and reality as separate but related
concepts, as several characters manipulate appearances to disguise the reality of their
intentions. Through the characters of Macbeth and Lady Macbeth, the Witches’ use of
ambiguous language and Macbeth’s visions, Shakespeare explores the complex relationship
between appearance and reality. The atmosphere of confusion and deception created by
these aspects of the play leaves both the characters and the audience questioning what
is real and what is not.
At the start of the play, Macbeth’s outward appearance and his inner reality are aligned.
Lady Macbeth acknowledges this when she describes his face as a “book” in which “men /
May read strange matters”. This metaphor suggests that, for Macbeth at this point in the
play, appearance and reality are one and the same, as his real intentions can be read as
easily as words on a page. Up until this point, Macbeth has been loyal to Duncan, and he
hasn’t yet learned to hide behind false appearances. This implies that trustworthiness can be
determined by whether or not someone’s appearance reects their reality.
Lady Macbeth’s use of gurative language emphasises how appearance can disguise
reality. She tells Macbeth to “look like th’innocent ower, / But be the serpent under’t.”
Flowers carry connotations of purity and snakes are often associated with evil, so by
juxtaposing these two contrasting images, Shakespeare encourages the audience to reect
on the extent to which appearance and reality can differ. This quote links to the Bible story
of the Garden of Eden, in which Satan disguised himself as a snake to trick Eve. This
foreshadows how Macbeth will ‘disguise’ himself as a loyal thane to kill Duncan.
AO1
: The analysis
is backed up by
relevant quotes.
